SUMMARY:  LATE FILED.  On October 4, 2017, Jeffrey Serfass, Executive Director, California Hydrogen Business Council (CHBC), met with Cmmr. Guzman Aceves simultaneously at the Commission’s offices in San Francisco and Sacramento.  Also present were Emanuel Wagner, Assistant Director, CHBC; V. John White of V. John White Associates, and Lorraine Paskett, chief executive officer of Cambridge LCF Group. Prior to the meeting, CHBC staff sent a document previously published to the 2017 IEPR docket, which discussed “Market Development Opportunities and Pathways for Renewable Hydrogen in California”. While no items relevant to R13-11-007 were discussed in the meeting, the document does reference parts of which may be relevant to this rulemaking. The document is publicly accessible at  http://docketpublic.energy.ca.gov/PublicDocuments/17-IEPR-12/TN220655_20170810T134122_California_Hydrogen_Business_Council_Comments_Market_Developmen.pdf.

(1) Pacific Gas and Electric Company, San Diego Gas & Electric Company, and Southern California Edison Company, are directed to file their first round of transportation electrification applications by January 20, 2017. AMENDED SCOPING MEMO AND RULING OF THE ASSIGNED COMMISSIONER AND ADMINISTRATIVE LAW JUDGE.  The categorization of this Rulemaking is quasi-legislative  as set forth in Section 6.  The scope of the proceeding is set forth in Section 2.  The procedural schedule is set forth in Section 5.  Since this Rulemaking is categorized as quasi-legislative, ex parte communications in this Rulemaking are permitted without any restrictions as provided for in Public Utilities Code § 1701.4 and Rule 8.3(a) of the Commission’s Rules of Practice and Procedure.  Carla J. Peterman is the presiding officer in this proceeding, and John S. Wong is the assigned Administrative Law Judge.

Decision D1601045 - Decision Regarding Underlying Vehicle Grid Integration Application and Motion to Adopt Settlement Agreement, closes proceeding A.14-04-014. A.14-04-014 is now de-consolidated from R.13-11-007 which remain open.

SUMMARY: On January 20, 2016, Billy Blattner, Manager of Regulatory Relations, San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E), met with Matthew Tisdale, advisor to Cmmr. Florio, and David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in two separate meetings in San Francisco.  At the meeting with David Gamson also present was Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman.  Dan Skopec, Vice President of Regulatory Affairs for SDG&E, participated in both meetings.  Blattner stated that SDG&E's Vehicle-Grid Integration (VGI) proposal and settlement were designed to be responsive to state policies and Commission guidance.  Blattner expressed concern that the Proposed Decision does not clearly provide for ongoing operations and maintenance.   Skopec indicated that such costs should be recorded and recovered in future rate proceedings.  Blattner stated that parties who claim that the model is invalid because it uses illustrative data are creating a Catch-22 where a program cannot be approved without data, but data cannot be generated without a program. Blattner also suggested that the proposed customer segment and location quotas are inconsistent with prior Commission guidance. In the meeting with Tisdale, Blattner also explained that demand response is essentially embedded within the VGI rate which benefits all ratepayers.

SUMMARY:  On January 15, 2016, Marcel Hawiger, staff attorney with The Utility Reform Network (TURN), met with Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman. Also present was Elise Torres, staff attorney with TURN. TURN representatives summarized TURN’s primary concerns regarding the proposed decision’s interpretation of § 740.3 and the meaning of “ratepayer interests.” Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

Description: Reply comments on Proposed Decision of Administrative Law Judge Wong.
Reply comments on the Proposed Decision.

SUMMARY: On Friday, January 8, 2016, Aaron Johnson, Vice President, Customer Energy Solutions Pacific Gas and Electric Company (PG&E), met with Joanna Gubman, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Also present were David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman; and Jana Corey, Director, Electrification and Alternative Fuels, and Sidney Dietz, Director, Regulatory Relations, for PG&E. Johnson explained that a diversity of approaches to electric vehicle (EV) charging infrastructure is appropriate. Corey described PG&E’s EV infrastructure and education program design, and stated that PG&E is carefully following the policy language found in the proposed and alternative proposed decisions on SCE’s and SDG&E’s EV applications. Corey described PG&E’s DC fast charger proposal. Johnson stated that restrictive allocations of EV charger site locations, like a 50/50 split between workplaces and multi-unit dwellings, would be difficult to implement and could slow the deployment of needed EV chargers. Johnson stated that more EV pilots are not needed. Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On January 11, 2016, Marcel Hawiger, staff attorney with The Utility Reform Network (TURN), met with Matthew Tisdale, advisor to Cmmr. Florio. Also present were Elise Torres, staff attorney, and Eric Borden, energy analyst, for TURN. TURN representatives summarized TURN’s primary concerns regarding the proposed decision’s interpretation of § 740.3 and the meaning of “ratepayer interests.” Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On Wednesday, December 16, 2015, Billy Blattner, Manager of Regulatory Relations for San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E), met with David Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco. Blattner discussed the status of SDG&E's Vehicle-Grid Integration Pilot proposal and settlement.  Blattner expressed SDG&E's frustration that a proposed decision was not issued by December 15.  Blattner indicated that SDG&E believes the settlement is reflective of the guidance given by the Commission and should be adopted.

Filed By: Green Power Institute,National Asian American Coalition
Description: JOINT; TO RESPONSES TO JOINT MOTION FOR A NEW TRACK FOCUSED ON EV EDUCATION AND OUTREACH

SUMMARY:  On October 21, 2015, Jim Baak, Program Director of Grid Integration for Vote Solar, met with David M. Gamson, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco.  Also present was Ehren Seybert, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman. Baak discussed overlapping issues between the Alternative Fuel Vehicles (AFV), Distribution Resource Planning (DRP), and Integration of Distributed Energy Resource (IDER) proceedings. Baak described Vote Solar's concerns about the misalignment between investor owned utility (IOU) revenue motivation and the goals of the DRP and greenhouse gas emission reductions. Baak suggested EV charging station programs and pilots include integration capacity analysis results as one of the site selection criteria, that IOUs evaluate other forms of DER to mitigate infrastructure upgrades, and implement demonstration or pilot programs to test new revenue models.

Filed By: The Utility Reform Network,Office of Ratepayer Advocates,Utility Consumers' Action Network
Description: JOINT. SUMMARY: On July 16, 2015, Iryna Kwasny, attorney for the Office of Ratepayer Advocates (ORA), met with Matthew Tisdale, advisor to Cmmr. Florio, in San Francisco.  Also present were Rajan Mutialu, Senior Analyst at ORA, and Marcel Hawiger, Staff Attorney at the Utility Reform Network, and Don Kelly, Executive Director of the Utility Consumers' Action Network, collectively "the Ratepayer Advocates."  The Ratepayer Advocates recommended the Commission to reject the proposed Settlement Agreement regarding San Diego Gas & Electric Company's Vehicle-Grid Integration (VGI) Pilot Program and reinstate the briefing schedule on the Application. The Ratepayer Advocates noted that unlike SDG&E's proposed settlement, the proposed settlement in SCE's application was an all-party settlement, and that it provided a much better model for developing utility EV infrastructure. If the Commission does not reject the proposed SDG&E Settlement Agreement, then the Ratepayer Advocates requested hearings on new factual issues raised by the modifications to the VGI program introduced in the proposed Settlement Agreement. Written materials (attached to the notice) were used.

SUMMARY:  LATE FILED. On Tuesday, May 5, 2015, Edward Kjaer, Director of Transportation Electrification, Southern California Edison Company (SCE), spoke at an all-party meeting attended by Cmmr. Peterman, Administrative Law Judges Moosen, Wong, and Hieta, and Jennifer Kalafut, advisor to Cmmr.  Peterman, in San Francisco.  Andrea Tozer, Senior Attorney, SCE, also spoke at the meeting.  Kjaer discussed issues related to the alternative-fueled vehicle proceedings, including: (1) consolidation of the proceedings is not necessary or appropriate; (2) pilot programs should be approved without delay, and should test different models in different service areas; and (3) marketing, education, and outreach might be an appropriate topic to be addressed in workshops in the Rulemaking proceeding. Tozer stated that although the record in A.14-04-014 was well developed and addressed many issues relevant to all the proceedings, the record in that proceeding is not sufficient to adjudicate SCE's Charge Ready application (A.14-10-014), because SCE was not a party to A.14-04-014.

SUMMARY:  On April 17, 2015, Jeremy Waen, Senior Regulatory Analyst, Marin Clean Energy, met with Jennifer Kalafut, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in the Commission's office. Also present were Rajan Mutialu, Analyst, Joseph Abhulimen, Program and Project Supervisor, and Iryna A. Kwasny, attorney, for the Office of Ratepayer Advocates; Anne Smart, Director of Government Relations and Regulatory Affairs, and Lynn Haug, attorney, for ChargePoint, Inc.; Tam Hunt, attorney, for the Green Power Institute; Mark Higgins, consultant for the California Energy Storage Alliance; Donald Kelly, Executive Director, for the Utility Consumers' Action Network; and Paul Hernandez, Energy and Transportation Policy Manager, for the Center for Sustainable Energy.  Elise Torres, Attorney, and Eric Borden, Energy Policy Analyst, for The Utility Reform Network; Jessica Tam, attorney, for the Joint Minority Parties; Brian Korpics, Policy Manager, for the Clean Coalition; and Ronald Liebert, attorney, for the California Manufacturers & Technology Association, participated in the meeting by telephone. The participants discussed the motions filed by varying parties that provide procedural recommendations and requests, and explained how the different Motions can be viewed as complementary to each other. The representatives also made recommendations for how the Commission might be able to respond and act upon these Motions.  Written material (attached to the notice) was used.

SUMMARY:  On March 2, 2015, Janice Lin, Executive Director of California Energy Storage Alliance (CESA) met with Jennifer Kalafut and Julie Fitch, advisors to Cmmr. Peterman, in two separate meetings in San Francisco.  Also present were Stacey Reineccius, President of Powertree Services, and Don Liddell, of Douglass & Liddell, on behalf of CESA.  Lin and Liddell discussed the significant chilling effect that San Diego Gas & Electric Company's (SDG&E) application for approval of its vehicle grid integration pilot program is having on development of nonutility electric vehicle charging stations in SDG&E's service territory.

SUMMARY:  on February 18, 2015, Mike Callahan-Dudley, Regulatory Counsel, Marin Clean Energy (MCE), met with Melicia Charles, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco.  Also present was Jeremy Waen, Regulatory Analyst, MCE.  MCE representatives discussed the three investor-owned utilities applications for projects to build electric vehicle service equipment and concerns related to competitive neutrality, ratepayer benefits, and low-income communities.  A written material, attached to the notice, was used.

SUMMARY: On February 12, 2015, Jim Baak, Program Director, Grid Integration, The  
Vote Solar Initiative (Vote Solar), met with Jennifer Kalafut, advisor to Cmmr. Peterman, in San Francisco.  Also present was Jill Yung of Paul Hastings LLP, outside counsel to Vote Solar.   
Baak expressed concern that the investor-owned utility charging pilot programs seem to be advancing well ahead of the rulemaking, which would ideally have provided guidance on how to structure vehicle charging projects to better manage the impact of renewable generation on grid performance.

SUMMARY: LATE FILED. On December 3, 2014, Jim Avery, Senior Vice President - Power Supply for San Diego Gas & Electric Company (SDG&E) spoke at an all-party meeting attended by Cmmrs. Peterman, Florio and Peevey in San Francisco. Also present were Laura McDonald, Director, Clean Transportation and Advanced Technology; Greg Haddow, Clean Transportation Manager; Greg Barnes, Senior Counsel; Parina Parikh, Regulatory Case Manager; and Billy Blattner, Manager of Regulatory Relations, for SDG&E.  Avery expressed SDG&E's support for the proposed decision (PD). He emphasized the importance of customer-managed charging as a tool to ensure that grid impacts are minimized and the benefits to ratepayers and the environment are realized. Avery also expressed appreciation that the PD recognizes that SDG&E's application presents the first opportunity for the Commission to consider different models to promote transportation electrification.
